hu.elte.txtuml.api

Class Model

  • java.lang.Object
    • hu.elte.txtuml.api.Action
      • hu.elte.txtuml.api.Model
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ModelElement

    public class Model
extends Action
    Base class of txtUML models. Read this documentation page further for an overview on modeling in txtUML.

    Represents: model

    Usage:

    Every element of the model must be nested classes of the same subclass of Model.

    Java restrictions:

    • Instantiate: disallowed
    • Define subtype: allowed

      Subtype requirements:

      • none

      Subtype restrictions:

      • Be abstract: disallowed
      • Generic parameters: disallowed
      • Constructors: disallowed
      • Initialization blocks: disallowed
      • Fields: disallowed
      • Methods: disallowed
      • Nested interfaces: disallowed
      • Nested classes: allowed, both static and non-static, to represent elements of the model; all nested classes must be subclasses of an API class representing a certain model element
      • Nested enums: disallowed
    • Inherit from the defined subtype: disallowed

    Example: 

     
 public class SampleModel extends Model {
 
        class SampleClass1 extends ModelClass {
                //...
        }
 
        class SampleClass2 extends ModelClass {
                //...
        }
  
        public static class SampleSignal extends Signal {}
  
        //...
 
 }

    Modeling in txtUML

    About Java restrictions

    A txtUML model is always a valid Java source but it must apply to other restrictions and requirements as well. All these special rules are detailed at the corresponding pages of this documentation. Read it carefully as currently no model validator is implemented for txtUML so the documentation is the only source of information about model validity. Offending these rules may cause unexpected behavior or errors without proper explanation or error messages.

    Note: many of these rules of writing txtUML models are only in the service of model exportation to EMF-UML2. Therefore, it is possible for a non-valid model to be executed correctly through the API, but produce errors when exporting that model to EMF-UML2.

    Main structure of a model

    A txtUML model consists of a single class m which has to be the subclass of Model. All parts of the model must be implemented as nested classes of m. As a general rule, the model may not refer to or use any code in any way that is from outside m, with a few exceptions, described below, in the 'Global Java restrictions' section.

    Supported features

    Model features

    • classes ( ModelClass ),
    • associations ( Association ),
    • navigable and non-navigable association ends with different multiplicities ( AssociationEnd ),
    • collections of model objects ( Collection ),
    • state machines ( StateMachine ) having
      • initial pseudostates ( StateMachine.Initial ),
      • states ( StateMachine.State ) with entry ( entry ) and exit ( exit ) actions,
      • transitions ( StateMachine.Transition ) with effects ( effect ) and guards ( guard ),
      • composite states ( StateMachine.CompositeState ) to implement hierarchical state machines,
      • choice pseudostates ( StateMachine.Choice ),
    • sending simple and parametric signals ( Signal, Action.send ),
    • linking, unlinking, querying associations ( Action.link, Action.unlink, ModelClass.assoc ),
    • model object deletion ( Action.delete ),
    • external classes to call out to native Java code ( ExternalClass ),
    • boolean, integer, string primitive types ( ModelInt, ModelBool, ModelString )
    • control structures and variables to use inside them ( Action.If, Action.While, Action.For, VariableType )
    • logging ( log, logError ),
    • changeable timers through the standard library ( Timer, Handle ).

    Executor features

    • initializing the model and sending signals to it from external code,
    • execution time, which makes it possible to speed up or slow down the model execution ( setExecutionTimeMultiplier ),
    • dynamic checks and error logging, like checking multiplicities or overlapping guards, some of which might be switched off due to their high cost at runtime ( setDynamicChecks ),
    • optional automatic logging ( setExecutorLog ),
    • setting custom PrintStreams to be used when logging ( setUserOutStream, setUserErrorStream, setExecutorOutStream, setExecutorErrorStream ).

    Global Java restrictions

    Allowed in the model

    • Using and extending classes, interfaces, enums and annotations of this package and the hu.elte.txtuml.api.blocks package, if the opposite is not stated on the corresponding pages of this documentation.
    • Using Java primitive types and Strings but only as parameters of constructors and setter methods of ModelType and VariableType classes and their subclasses, and logging methods of Action ( log, logError ).
    • Using subclasses of ExternalClass, like the classes of the hu.elte.txtuml.stdlib package. See the documentation of ExternalClass for details.

    Disallowed in the model

    • Using or extending any type not included in the preceding list, including Java built-in types (with the exception of java.lang.Object).
    • Any kind of control structures (if, while, do for, synchronized, switch statements).
    • Exception handling.
    • Defining enums, interfaces or abstract classes.
    • Defining synchronized, native or abstract methods.
    • Defining local classes.
    • Using the instanceof or the ternary ? : operator.
    • Equality checks with operators == or !=, including null-checking (null values should be avoided in the model).
    • Overriding or explicitly using the methods of java.lang.Object, with the exception of the use of the toString method which might be used only for logging.
    • Creating or managing threads.

    Communicating with the 'outside world'

    A txtUML model may never run by itself. It has to be managed or at least started from the outside. As ModelExecutor (the class which is responsible for executing models) uses its own thread, there are two main cases of accessing the model from the outside:

    • The model is accessed from another thread (that is, not the executor's thread).
    • The model calls a method of a class that is not part of the model (only allowed if that class extends ExternalClass), and then the model is accessed from that method (on the executor's thread).

    For details about the second case, see the documentation of ExternalClass. In the first case, when the model is accessed from another thread, only the following actions might be performed:

    • Create model objects (instances of subclasses of ModelClass) by either calling their constructors or using the Action.create method. Instantiating the model class m (the subclass of Model which encloses the whole model) is also allowed but is not required, neither has any effect on a well-defined model.
    • Use the static methods of the Action class to link, unlink, start or delete model objects that have not been started yet (the start method was not yet called with the corresponding model object as its parameter).
    • Change fields or call methods of model objects that have not been started yet. Calling methods is only allowed if the method itself also follows these rules.
      Note: the ModelClass.assoc method applies to this rule.
    • Create instances of signal types (subclasses of Signal) and set their fields before they are sent to the model (with the Action.send method).
    • Use the send method to send signals to a model object that has already been started.
    • Call Action.log or Action.logError at any time.
    • Call ModelClass.getIdentifier to get the unique identifier of a model object at any time.

    Definitions

    This section is for some important definitions about txtUML which are referenced throughout this documentation.

    Action code

    Java code blocks that contain txtUML action code may contain any Java code that follows the rules set in the 'Global Java restrictions' section.

    The most important features of the txtUML action language (the following list is not restrictive):

    • Using the Action class and its static methods to
      • create, link, unlink, delete model objects,
      • send signals asynchronously to model objects,
      • implement control structures.
    • Getting/setting fields of model objects (as UML attributes), calling their methods (as UML operations).
    • Querying association ends with the ModelClass.assoc method, using the result through the Collection interface.
    • Using subclasses of ExternalClass to bring external features into the model or to communicate with components of the program that are not part of the model.

    Condition evaluation

    A condition evaluation in txtUML is a Java code block which aims to create a ModelBool value that represents either true or false whether a certain condition about the model (which condition the block represents) holds or not.

    Condition evaluations in txtUML include guards of transitions, conditions of If statements and certain Collection methods ( selectAll ).

    A condition evaluation is exported to EMF-UML2 as a single model query, so it may include only the following actions:

    • Defining, modifying local variables.
    • Getting (but not setting) fields of model objects and signals.
    • Querying association ends with the ModelClass.assoc method.
    • Creating new ModelType or Collection instances with methods of those two types or their subtypes. (As all such instances are immutable, this does not affect the state of the model in any way.)
    • Calling methods of model objects as operations.

    Execution step

    An execution step starts when an asynchronous event (like a signal event) is chosen by the executor to be processed and ends when that event and all the synchronous events caused by it (like a state machine changing state, entry and exit actions, transition effects, operation calls) have been processed.

    Author:
    Gabor Ferenc Kovacs
    See Also:
